Authors:
Akira Hashimoto, Hiroshi Masumoto, Rikiya Endoh, Yousuke
Degawa, Moriya Ohkuma
Title:
Revision of Xylonaceae (Xylonales, Xylonomycetes) to include
Sarea and Tromera
Abstract:
The resinicolous fungi Sarea difformis and S. resinae are
taxonomically revised on the basis of morphological observations and
phylogenetic analyses of nucleotide sequences of
nSSU-LSU-mtSSU-rpb1-rpb2 genes. A total of 30 sequences were newly
obtained from five isolates of S. difformis and S. resinae. Phylogenetic
analyses suggested that these two species are grouped with Trinosporium
guianense and Xylona hevae (Xylonoaceae, Xylonales, Xylonomycetes), and
should be affiliated to Xylonomycetes. Based on morphological
observations, S. difformis and S. resinae can be distinguished at the
generic level. Thus, Tromera is retained as the natural genus to
accommodate T. resinae (= S. resinae). Xylonomycetes was morphologically
re-circumscribed to comprise of four genera, Sarea, Trinosporium,
Tromera and Xylona, which are shared having endophytic or saprobic stage
on various plant in their lifecycle, ascostroma-type ascomata with
paraphysoid and Lecanora-type bitunicate asci with thick-walled apex,
and pycnidial asexual morphs in their morphology. Although
Symbiotaphrinales is treated as member of Xylonomycetes in previous
studies, the order is characterized by having paraphyses with
non-thickened at apex and poorly differentiated bitunicate asci with
thin-walled apex in sexual morph as a saprobe on higher plants, and
yeast stage in asexual morph as a symbiont with the gut of arthropods,
which are clearly different from those of other members in
Xylonomycetes. Thus, we treat Symbiotaphrinales as Pezizomycotina
incertae sedis. Phylogenetic analyses based on ITS sequence with
environmental DNA (eDNA) were also conducted to clarify their habitats
and the results implied their worldwide distributions.
